data.title: Sort "Open Editors" by name, folder, etc

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: There doesn't seem to be any way at present of sorting the "Open Editors" section of the explorer menu by name or similar.  If I can't find a tab I tend to then look in Open Editors, but due to the inability to sort it can be almost as difficult to then find what I need.  I think the ability to sort by name at least would be a big improvement.

data.title: 'when' clause can not support the configurations who have string values.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: *

It seems ContextKeyExpr supports this form of  'when' clause: "config.myextension.somekey == 'abc' ", the value field is a string, but ContextKeyService 's member '_contexts' only contains configurations of those who's value are type of boolean.

Set VS code locale to Spanish 2. Open Tasks (Tareas) menu from system Menu Bar The general rule for capitalization appears to be to capitalize just the first word, so "Ejecutar Tarea" should be "Ejecutar tarea" to match the same style

data.title: Tasks - npm task provider should not provide pre, post tasks
data.body:
extracted from #1777

I actually came here looking to tone auto-detection down a bit -- it's detecting all my pre/post tasks as well as the ones I actually want to run.  It looks like it selects "configured" tasks first, so this isn't a huge issue, but it'd be nice to be able to hide some NPM tasks completely (and/or not show pre/post tasks in the first place).

data.title: No longer seeing console output
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
pgsql|dou|0.0.8
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
JSDocTagComplete|Hoo|0.0.2
vscode-esformatter|how|1.5.2
output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.2
vscode-puglint|mrm|2.3.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start a program that uses bunyan for logging.
2. To make the bunyan output readable, pipe the output through bunyan-cli.
To do so, create a `pipe-bunyan.cmd` with the following content:
```
@ECHO OFF
node %* | bunyan -o short
```
3. Specify the script as a `runtimeExecutable`, like so:
```
"runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}\\.scripts\\pipe-bunyan.cmd",
```

There is no output in the debug console. This used to work fine before.

data.title: Use workspace/folder settings when file is opened outside of workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Given a workspace `foo`, if file `foo/bar` is opened in VSCode standalone (not inside the `foo` workspace`), any settings in `foo/.vscode/settings.json` will not be picked up.

This matters when [using VSCode as a git mergetool](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5770). VSCode will open a file an editor to present the merge conflict, but the editor will not respect workspace settings. One example is where this is significant is formatter settings (like Prettier). Formatting the file will not respect project settings.

I understand workspace settings are specifically related to workspaces in VSCode, but I can't help but wonder if it makes sense to have "folder" settings which can be inherited from any parent folder for a given file. Has this idea been discussed?

data.title: Terminal sometimes loses the ability to scroll
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:  none

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch code.
2. Run build task.

At the time, there was a compiler error in my project, so the standard npm error stuff got output to the console, but I was unable to scroll up to see what tsc had output. Restarting vscode had no effect.

This is the error I get on the developer console when I click on the terminal window to give it focus:
```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'NaN' of undefined
    at SelectionManager._onSingleClick (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:228:71)
    at SelectionManager._onMouseDown (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:192:22)
    at HTMLDivElement.SelectionManager._initListeners._mouseDownListener (C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\xterm\lib\SelectionManager.js:53:67)
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Show Workspace name as Files Explorer section name
data.body:
Currently we have two kinds of workspaces

- Folder: Opening a folder in VS Code. Existing use case, where majority of users use. Always how the root folder as section. 

- Workspace: A use case where a user creates a Workspace with one or many folders. Always show the name of the workspace as section title. Otherwise it is hard to discover the name of the workspace.

data.title: Typescript file syntax highlighting
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- aurelia|Aur|0.3.4 python|don|0.6.7 tslint|eg2|0.16.0 csharp|ms-|1.11.0 vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create new Typescript file and paste the code: ``` this.myMethod({ "attribution": "bla, bla" }); L.tileLayer.wms("http://tempuri.org"); ``` Because of "<" in "<a>bla, bla</a>", ending of the last line "//tempuri.org" is highlited as a comment. Delete "<" and highlighting works properly. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature Request: JSON Schema - Allow root level configuration of "defaultSnippets"
data.body:
Some extensions have very flexible and powerful configuration options, and sometimes these configuration options should be set together.

For example, for VS Code Power mode, I have included a few examples in the README of settings that when used together will have a certain effect. I'd like to make it easy for users to add those to their settings using snippets.

Ideally I would like users to be able to start typing "powermode" in settings.json and have a snippet suggestion show up that would complete to:

```
"powermode.enabled": true,
"powermode.enableShake": false
```

Unfortunately, the only way I've been able to do this is to create a "powermode" entry in my configuration like this:

```
"powermode": {
    "type": "object",
    "defaultSnippets": [
        {
            "label": "No shake",
            "body": {
                "enabled": true,
                "enableShake": false
            }
        }
    ]
},
```

The problem with this, though, is that the convention is to define settings in a single level, i.e. as "powermode.enabled" and "powermode.enableShake". I can go against this and define all my settings as properties on "powermode", but I'd rather not.

But there is one more reason why snippets in the root level are useful: It would allow people to contribute snippets that set settings across multiple extensions/built in settings.

In my case, "combos" in powermode rely on having the status bar visible, so adding `"workbench.statusBar.visible": true` might make sense.

data.title: Expose document.hidden
data.body:
It would be helpful if VSC exposed `document.hidden` via an API, so that extensions could take advantage of it in order to skip some work.

Just to provide a concrete use case: I've made an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=fabiospampinato.vscode-github-notifications-bell) that calls a GitHub API endpoint every X seconds, the problem is that if I have N workspaces the extension will make N requests instead of 1, it would be better if it could avoid making requests for hidden workspaces.

What do you think?

data.title: Ubuntu Icon option seems to require a full path.
data.body:
The contents of `/usr/share/applications/code.desktop`

Includes 

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Visual Studio Code
Comment=Code Editing. Redefined.
GenericName=Text Editor
Exec=/usr/share/code/code --unity-launch %U
Icon=code
```

If I change this use an absolute path

\-  `Icon=code`
\+ `Icon=/usr/share/code/resources/app/resources/linux/code.png`

I get the expected icon showing. 

But this is undone on the next update.

data.title: Enable Text/Code Wrapping
data.body:
It's been a month when I started using Visual Basic Code, I try this and I love to use it in every day coding due to its extension, plug-ins and theme, even though this make me mesmerize with the application, but I even  still compare this to other text editors such as Sublime, Atom and Notepad++ and one behavior.

> The one that I compare is the word wrapping, this behavior of this application that really bugged and annoyed me. Whenever I would browse a document I would always get frustrated by the way the application would horizontally scroll whenever a document had really long lines of code. 

Is there's a possibility for me or us to enhanced word wrap or make a soft automatic text or command wrapping?

data.title: 'when' clause for if the editor is showing welcome page [Feature Request]

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14

I would like to set a shortcut to trigger only on the Welcome page. For example, `Ctrl+R` in my editor maps to both `Find symbol` and `Open Recent`.

What I would like to achieve is something like this

```
    {
      "key": "ctrl+r",
      "when" : "inWelcomePage",
      "command": "-workbench.action.gotoSymbol"
    },
```

data.title: vscode.workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument callback not called

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In my extension, I'm opening a local file using `vscode.workspace.openTextDocument` and then `vscode.window.showTextDocument`.  And it seems to be working fine.

I'm also listening for events using `vscode.workspace.onDidOpenTextDocument`,  `vscode.workspace.onDidSaveTextDocument` and `vscode.workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument`.

Both `vscode.workspace.onDidOpenTextDocument` and  `vscode.workspace.onDidSaveTextDocument` callbacks are called as expected. However 
`vscode.workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument` callback is not called when I close the file in the UI.

Am I missing anything?

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the file using `vscode.workspace.openTextDocument` and then `vscode.window.showTextDocument`;
2. Listen for events in `vscode.workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument`.
3. Close the file in the editor;
4. Check that `vscode.workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument` callback is not called as expected. 

Reproduces without extensions: It is the extension code that is not working.

data.title: QuickPickOptions unusable typings small fix
Remove inner whitespace on Toggle Block Comment. Fixes #30656 & #30729
Visual Studio Code Server
data.body:
Hi,

I'd like to ask about feature that came recently to my mind.
Let's say that we have Vagrant or just plain VM.
Let's say we use Rust or similiar programming language where we have appropriate extensions for VSCode, but they require some time and knowledge to setup (Rust Language Server etc.).
Let's say that we have beginner programmers that may use Windows, Linux or Mac and it's cumbersome for them to setup development environment themselves, so it should be possible to just download code, run prepared Vagrant VM and have everything up and running.

Now, it would be nice if this virtual machine had some "Visual Studio Code Server" (and that's my requested feature), so we would have Visual Studio Code on our host machine that can connect to this server on VM (ssh?), use server's configuration, plugins and allow to browse file, folders, execute commands provided by extensions, use terminal, remotely.

I can see huge value in this feature, because it would allow to provide seamless, friendly experience, even for most complicated projects.
